oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Soldiers preparing to leave on patrol
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eleven soldiers in a squad about to go on a patrol around the signal base on Vung Chua Mountain. A soldier in front of the group poses with an M-60 machine gun. He has belts of ammunition for the weapon over both shoulders. The soldiers in the background carry M-16s and have belts of ammunition over their shoulders as well. All wear boonie hats.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military personnel; Soldiers; Uniforms; Military uniforms; Hats; Arms & armament
United States. Army. Military Police Company, 194th; Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: According to Ammons, regulations for carrying ammunition for the M-60 machine gun were relaxed for patrols around Vung Chua Mountain. During his first tour in the front lines of the delta, he said, ammunition was stored in boxes. These boxes were hard to carry, but kept the rounds clean and prevented jamming. On Vung Chua ammunition was carried more casually whenever the threat of enemy attack was reduced.
